content.question: The conventional view of pre-industrial economies as incapable of sustained economic growth was in part informed by which of the following assumptions?

choices.label: Early modern Western Europe had a unique “European marriage pattern” of high age at first marriage and high rates of celibacy.
Before the middle of the eighteenth century, the European population was subject to Malthusian crises.
The expansion of overseas trade was crucial to Europe’s economic growth in the early modern period.
Countries’ mobilization for warfare was key to economic development in early modern Europe.

content.answer: Before the middle of the eighteenth century, the European population was subject to Malthusian crises.
